Questions.Question: The indication on the instrument display that represents the far boundary of the material being tested is called:
In immersion testing, the position of the transducer is often varied by a manipulator to transmit sound into the test part at various angles to the front surface. Such a procedure is referred to as:
The technical name for the cable that connects the ultrasonic instrument to the transducer is:
The process of standardizing an instrument or device by using a reference standard is called:
Another name for a compressional wave is:
Another name for rayleigh waves is:
A material used between the face of a transducer and the test surface to permit or improve the transmission of ultrasonic vibrations from the transducer to the material being tested is called:
The piezoelectric material in a transducer that vibrates to produce ultrasonic waves is called a:
Ultrasonic testing of material where the probe is in direct contact with the material being tested may be:
An advantage of using lithium sulfate in transducers is that it:

Answers.Text: is one of the most efficient generators of ultrasonic energy.
is one of the most efficient receivers of ultrasonic energy.
can withstand temperatures as high as 700 °C (1260 °F).

Questions.Question: The transducer that contains the thinnest piezoelectric crystal is a:
Penetration of ultrasonic waves in a material is normally the function of test frequency use The greatest depth of penetration is provided by a frequency of:
The amount of beam divergence from a crystal is primarily dependent on the:

Answers.Text: tightness of crystal backing in the transducer.

Questions.Question: When an ultrasonic beam passes through the interface between two dissimilar materials at an angle, a new angle of sound travel takes place in the second material due to:
The velocity of longitudinal waves is approximately ___ the velocity of shear waves in the same material.
Under most circumstances, which of the following frequencies would result in the best resolving power?
Which of the following materials of the same alloy is most likely to produce the greatest amount of sound attenuation over a given distance?

Answers.Text: The attenuation is equal in all materials.

Questions.Question: In contact testing, the entry surface indication is sometimes referred to as the:
An ultrasonic instrument display pattern containing a large number oflow-level indications (often referred to as grass or hash) could be caused by:
A test method employing two separate transducers on opposite surfaces of the material being tested is called:
The number of complete waves that pass a given point in a given period of time (usually 1 s) is referred to as the:
The boundary between two different materials that are in contact with each other is called:
When the motion of the particles of a medium is parallel to the direction of propagation, the wave being transmitted is called a:
When the motion of the particles of a medium is transverse to the direction of propagation, the wave being transmitted is called a:
The number "25 million cycles per second" can also be stated as:
Moving a transducer over a test surface either manually or automatically is referred to as:
A term used in ultrasonics to express the rate at which sound waves pass through various substances is:
When an indication has reached the maximum signal height which can be displayed or viewed on the display of an ultrasonic instrument, the indication is said to have reached its:
An ultrasonic testing technique in which the transducer element is not parallel to the test  surface is called:
Most commercial ultrasonic testing is accomplished using frequencies between:
In an A-scan presentation, the horizontal baseline represents the:

Answers.Text: amount of reflected ultrasonic sound energy.

Questions.Question: In an A-scan presentation, the amplitude of vertical indications on the display represents the:

Answers.Text: amount of ultrasonic sound energy returning to the transducer.
elapsed time since the ultrasonic pulse was generate

Questions.Question: Which of the following test frequencies would generally provide the best penetration in a 305 mm (12 in.) thick specimen of coarse-grained steel?
In a basic ultrasonic test pattern (A-scan) for contact testing (assuming no sweep delay is used), the initial pulse is:

Answers.Text: the high indication on the extreme left side of the display that represents the entry surface of the inspected part.
the first pulse that occurs near the right side of the display and represents the opposite boundary of the inspected part.
an indication that appears and disappears during screening.
always the second pulse from the left on the viewing display.

Questions.Question: An ultrasonic test using a straight beam contact transducer is being conducted through the thickness of a flat part such as a plate. This test should detect:

Answers.Text: laminar-type discontinuities with major dimensions parallel to the rolled surface.
transverse-type discontinuities with major dimensions at right angles to the rolled surface.
radial discontinuities with major dimensions along length but radially oriented to the rolled surface.

Questions.Question: In ultrasonic testing, a liquid coupling medium between the crystal surface and the part surface is necessary because:

Answers.Text: lubricant is required to minimize wear on the crystal surface.
an air interface between the crystal surface and the part surface would almost completely reflect the ultrasonic vibrations.
the crystal will not vibrate if placed directly in contact with the surface of the part being inspected
the liquid is necessary to complete the electrical circuit in the transducer.

Questions.Question: Near-surface resolution is a characteristic of an ultrasonic testing system that defines its ability to detect:

Answers.Text: discontinuities oriented in a direction parallel to the ultrasonic beam.
discontinuities located in the center of a forging containing a fine metallurgic structure.
discontinuities located just beneath the entry-surface in the part being teste

Questions.Question: During ultrasonic testing by the immersion method, it is frequently necessary to angulate the transducer when a discontinuity is located in order to:

Answers.Text: avoid a large number of back reflections that could interfere with a normal test pattern.
obtain a maximum response if the discontinuity is not originally oriented perpendicular to the ultrasonic beam.
obtain the maximum number of entry surface reflections.
obtain a discontinuity indication of the same height as the indication from the flat-bottom hole in a reference block.

Questions.Question: All other factors being equal, the mode of vibration that has the greatest velocity is the:
On the area-amplitude ultrasonic standard test blocks, the flat-bottom holes in the blocks are:

Answers.Text: different in diameter, increasing by 0.4 mm (0.016 in.) increments from the No. 1 block to the No. 8 block.
largest in the No. 1 block and smallest in the No. 8 block.
drilled to different depths from the front surface of the test block.

Questions.Question: In immersion testing, verification that the transducer is normal to a flat entry surface is indicated by:

Answers.Text: maximum reflection from the entry surface.
maximum amplitude of the initial pulse.

Questions.Question: A piezoelectric material can:

Answers.Text: convert a longitudinal beam to a shear wave.
convert a mechanical energy to electrical energy.
create ionization in a test specimen.
produce sound waves in a coaxial cable.

Questions.Question: Sound waves of a frequency beyond the hearing range of the human ear are referred to as ultrasonic waves or vibrations, and the term embraces all vibrational waves of frequency greater than approximately:
The velocity of sound waves is primarily dependent on the: ·
The primary purpose of reference blocks is to:

Answers.Text: aid the operator in obtaining maximum back reflections.
obtain the greatest sensitivity possible from an instrument.

Questions.Question: When testing by the surface wave method, patches of oil or dirt on the surface may:

Answers.Text: block the progress of all sound
have no effect on the test.
cause both an attenuation of sound and indications on the screen.

Questions.Question: In immersion testing, the most commonly used couplant is:
The piezoelectric material in the transducer:

Answers.Text: converts electrical energy into mechanical energy and mechanical energy into electrical energy.

Questions.Question: The shortest wavelength pulse is produced by a frequency of:
The angle of incidence is:

Answers.Text: greater than the angle of reflection.
less than the angle of reflection.
equal to the angle of reflection.
not related to the angle of reflection.

Questions.Question: On many ultrasonic testing instruments, an operator conducting an immersion test can remove that portion of the display presentation that represents water distance by adjusting a:
What is another way to express 100 000 cycles per second?
A transducer with a frequency greater than 10 MHz will most likely be used during:

Answers.Text: a straight beam contact test of aluminum ingot.
an angle beam contact test of a steel pipe.
a surface wave contact test of a metallic plate.

Questions.Question: The reference holes in standard aluminum area-amplitude ultrasonic test blocks contain:
The gradual loss of sonic energy as the ultrasonic vibrations travel through the material is referred to as:
A term used to describe numerous small indications on the instrument display resulting from test part structure, numerous small discontinuities, or both is often referred to as:
When testing a plate, increasing the frequency of an ultrasonic longitudinal wave results in:
Ultrasonic waves transmitted into and received from the test material in the form of repetitive bursts of acoustic energy is called:
Metal blocks, which contain one or more drilled holes or notches to simulate discontinuities, are called:
If the major dimensions of a discontinuity in a 152 mm (6 in.) thick aluminum plate lie parallel to the entry surface at a depth of 76 mm (3 in.), it will be best detected by:
The presence of a discontinuity will not produce a specific discontinuity indication on the ultrasonic instrument display when using the:
The depth of a discontinuity cannot be determined when using the:
When inspecting coarse-grained material, a sound wave is most easily scattered by the grain structure by a frequency of:
The thickest crystal is contained in a:
When performing a surface wave test, indications may result from:

Which of the following discontinuities located 152 mm (6 in.) from the entry surface results in the largest display indication if all factors except discontinuity surface condition and orientation are the same?

Answers.Text: 2 mm (0.08 in.) diameter flat-surfaced discontinuity whose major face is at an angle of 75° from the direction of sound beam propagation.
2 mm (0.08 in.) diameter rough-surfaced discontinuity whose major face is at an angle of 75° from the direction of sound beam propagation.
2 mm (0.08 in.) diameter flat-surfaced discontinuity whose major face is perpendicular to the direction of sound beam propagation.
2 mm (0.08 in.) diameter rough-surfaced discontinuity whose major face is parallel to the direction of sound beam propagation.

Questions.Question: Transducers constructed with a plastic wedge or standoff between the transducer element and the test piece are commonly used:

Answers.Text: to eliminate the need for a couplant.
to reduce the speed of electrons.

Questions.Question: Sound can be focused by special curved adapters located in front of the transducer element. These adapters are referred to as:
A test method in which the parts to be inspected are placed in a water bath or some other liquid couplant is called:
A separate time baseline imposed on the viewing display of some ultrasonic testing instruments that permits measurement of distances is often referred to as:
A term used to describe the ability of an ultrasonic testing system to distinguish between the entry-surface response and the response of discontinuities near the entry surface is:
The phenomenon whereby an ultrasonic wave changes direction when the wave crosses a boundary between materials with different velocities is called:
In a test where the transducer is not perpendicular to the inspection surface, the angle of incidence is equal to:

The product of the acoustic velocity of sound in a material and the density of the material is the factor that determines the amount of reflection or transmission of ultrasonic energy when it reaches an interface. This is called:
Ultrasonic waves that travel along the surface of a material and whose particle motion is elliptical are called:
The interference field near the face of a transducer is often referred to as the:
When the incident angle is chosen to be between the first and second critical angles, the ultrasonic wave mode within the part will be a:
The formula used to calculate the angle of refraction within a material is called:
In a material with a given velocity, when frequency is increased, the wavelength will:
Circuits that electronically amplify return signals from the receiving transducer and often modify the signals into a form suitable for display are called:
The most common type of data display used for ultrasonic examination of welds is:
The display that plots signal amplitude versus time is called:
A circuit that modifies the return signal from the receiving transducer into a form suitable for display on an oscilloscope or other output device is called a:
A circuit that generates a burst of voltage that is applied to the sending transducer is called:
A circuit that coordinates electronic operation of the entire ultrasonic instrument system is called:
A plan view display or recording of a part under examination is called:
Ultrasonic data, which is presented in a form representative of the cross section of the test specimen, is called:
What type of ultrasonic examination uses wheel-type transducers that eliminate the use of a tank?
In addition to other functions, a transducer manipulator in a mechanical immersion-scanning unit permits:
A type of data presentation most likely to be used with a high-speed automatic scanning system is:

Answers.Text: a plot of echo height versus depth.

Questions.Question: The component in a conventional immersion system that spans the width of the immersion tank is called:
The component in an ultrasonic immersion system that is used to adjust and maintain a known transducer angle is called:
An amplitude type gate is necessary for all:
When a C-scan recording is used to produce a permanent record of an ultrasonic test, the information displayed is typically the discontinuity's:
Rough entry surface conditions can result in:

Answers.Text: an increase in echo amplitude from discontinuities.
a decrease in the width of the front-surface echo.
a loss of amplitude from discontinuities.

Questions.Question: As the grain size increases in a material, its principal effect in ultrasonic testing is on the:

In straight beam pulse echo testing, a discontinuity with a rough reflecting surface perpendicular to the incident wave has what effect on the detected signal in comparison to a smooth flat-bottom hole of the same size?

Answers.Text: It has no effect on the detected signal.
It decreases the width of the pulse of the detected signal.

Questions.Question: Which material can only transmit longitudinal waves?
If the velocity of a longitudinal mode wave in a given homogeneous material is 0.625 cm/μs at 13 mm (0.5 in.) below the surface, what is the velocity at 51 mm (2 in.) below the surface?

Answers.Text: One-fourth the velocity at 13 mm (0.5 in.).
One-half the velocity at 13 mm (0.5 in.).
The same as the velocity at 13 mm (0.5 in.).
Three-fourths the velocity at 13 mm (0.5 in.)

Questions.Question: What effect will replacing a 2.25 MHz transducer with a 5 MHz transducer have on the wavelength?

Answers.Text: Increase it and the acoustic impedance.

Questions.Question: What can cause nonrelevant indications on the A-scan display?

Answers.Text: Setting a low pulse repetition rate.
Small grain structure of test specimens.

Questions.Question: The proper interpretation and evaluation of the presented discontinuity signals are essential to any nondestructive test. A common method for the estimation of discontinuity size is the use of:
Another name for fresnel zone is:
Attenuation is a:
To evaluate discontinuities that are oriented at an angle to the entry surface so that the sound beam strikes the plane of the discontinuity at right angles, the operator must:
The pulser circuit in an ultrasonic instrument is used to:

Answers.Text: control the horizontal and vertical sweep.
control transducer timing between transmit and sweep.
generate markers that appear on horizontal sweep.

Questions.Question: An A-scan display, which shows a signal both above and below the sweep line, is called:
AB-scan display shows the relative:

Answers.Text: distance a discontinuity is from the transducer and its through-dimension thickness.
distance a discontinuity is from the transducer and its length in the direction of transducer travel.
cross-sectional area of a discontinuity above a predetermined amplitude.
pulse height and time of arrival to produce a plan-view image.

Questions.Question: Surface (rayleigh) waves traveling on the top face of a block:

Answers.Text: are not reflected from a sharp edge corner.
are reflected from a sharp edge corner.
travel through the sharp edge corner and are reflected from the lower edge.
are absorbed by a sharp edge corner.

Questions.Question: Surface (rayleigh) waves are more highly attenuated by a:
The velocity of sound in a material is dependent upon the:
To vary or change the wavelength of sound being  used to test a part, change the:
Ultrasonic vibrations are commonly used to:

Answers.Text: detect discontinuities in multilayered structures having air gaps between layers.
perform volumetric examinations of ferrous and nonferrous materials.

Questions.Question: Which of the following has the longest fresnel zone?
When contact testing, if the ultrasonic instrument is set with an excessively high pulse repetition frequency:

Answers.Text: the screen trace becomes too light to see.
UT signals may overlap with the multiples of the backwall echoes.

Questions.Question: The advantages of immersion testing include:
Longitudinal wave velocity in water is approximately one-fourth the velocity in aluminum or steel. Therefore,. the minimum water path should be:

Answers.Text: four times the test piece thickness.
one-fourth the test piece thickness plus 6 mm (0.25 in.).
one-half the test piece thickness plus 6 mm (0.25 in.)

Questions.Question: In immersion testing, a wetting agent is added to the water to:

Answers.Text: help eliminate the formation of air bubbles.

Questions.Question: The formula used to determine the fundamental resonant frequency is:
If frequency is increased, wavelength:

Answers.Text: remains the same but velocity increases.
remains the same but velocity decreases.

Questions.Question: The variable in distance amplitude calibration block construction is the:

Answers.Text: metal distance above the drilled hole.
angle of the drilled hole to block longitudinal axis.

Questions.Question: When setting up a distance amplitude correction curve using three flat-bottom holes, sometimes the hole closest to the transducer gives less of a response than one or both of the other two. This could be caused by:

Answers.Text: a hole that is too large.

Questions.Question: Ferrous and nonferrous welds may be ultrasonically tested using a frequency range of:
The product of the material density and the velocity of sound within that material is referred to as:
A straight beam contact transducer consists of:

Answers.Text: a case, a crystal, wear plate, and backing.
a case, a crystal, backing, and a plastic wedge.
a case, a crystal, backing, and acoustic lenses.
a case, a crystal, a mount, backing, a plastic wedge, and acoustic lenses.

Questions.Question: In immersion testing, to remove the second water reflection from between the entry surface signal and the first back reflection, you should:
For a given incident angle, as the frequency of the transducer increases, the refracted angle:
Both longitudinal and shear waves may be simultaneously generated in a second medium when the angle of incidence is:

Answers.Text: between normal and the first critical angle.
between the first and second critical angles.
only at the second critical angle.

Questions.Question: Penetration of ultrasonic waves in a material is normally the function of test frequency use The greatest depth of penetration is provided by a frequency of:
Refracted energy assumes a new direction of propagation when the is change
The loss of energy as it propagates through material is the result of beam:
In selecting a suitable couplant, which of the following characteristics would not affect the selection?
Excessive surface roughness of the material being tested can cause:

Answers.Text: a loss of echo amplitude from discontinuities within the material.

Questions.Question: Reference or calibration standards are used for:

Answers.Text: providing a method for standardizing the test system.

Questions.Question: The change in direction of an ultrasonic beam when it passes from one material to another material in which elasticity and density differ is called:
If a discontinuity is oriented at an angle other than 90° to the sound beam, the results may be a:

Answers.Text: loss or lack of signal reflected from the discontinuity.

Questions.Question: A device that transforms electrical pulses into mechanical and vice versa utilizes:
Whenever an ultrasonic incident angle is set at 5° from normal in water:

Answers.Text: the refracted wave is mode converted
the refracted wave is the same mode as the incident wave.
the refracted wave in steel has two components,
one of which will be the same mode as the incident wave.

Questions.Question: If a discontinuity is located in the fresnel or near-field region of a sound beam:

Answers.Text: the larger the discontinuity, the larger the amplitude of the reflected signal.
the closer to the surface the discontinuity is located, the larger will be the amplitude of the reflected signal.
in immersion testing, the amplitude of the signal increases as the water path decreases.
in immersion testing, the amplitude of the reflected signal may increase or decrease as the water path decreases.

Questions.Question: If a transducer is vibrating at a frequency and injecting ultrasonic energy through water into a steel specimen:

Answers.Text: the sound wavelength is the same in both the water and the steel.
the sound frequency in the water is less than the sound frequency in steel.
the sound wavelength is not the same in both the water and the steel.
the sound frequency in the water is greater than the sound frequency in steel.

Questions.Question: When a longitudinal sound wave strikes a watersteel interface at an angle of incidence of 15°

Answers.Text: all the sound energy is reflected back into the water at an angle of 15°.
part of the sound energy is reflected at 15° and part is refracted into the steel at an angle of less than 15°.
part of the sound energy is reflected at 15° and part is refracted along the water-steel interface.
part of the sound energy is reflected at 15° and part is refracted into the steel at an angle greater than 15°.
